speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, and welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I have one overarching goal: to sustain the economic expansion, with a strong job market and stable prices, for the benefit of the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the FOMC meeting that concluded today, we maintained our policy interest rate but made some significant changes to our statement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since the beginning of the year, we have judged that our current policy stance was broadly appropriate and that we should be patient in assessing the need for any changes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In light of increased uncertainties and muted inflation pressures, we now emphasize that the Committee will closely monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook and will act as appropriate to sustain the expansion with a strong labor market and inflation near its 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d like to step back and review how the changing economic and financial picture brings us to today’s decision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So far this year, the economy has performed reasonably well, with solid fundamentals supporting continued growth and strong employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has been running somewhat below our objective, but we have expected it to pick up, supported by solid growth and a strong job market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Along with this favorable picture, we have been mindful of some ongoing crosscurrents, including trade developments and concerns about global growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the time of our last FOMC meeting, which ended on May 1, there was tentative evidence that these crosscurrents were moderating.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The latest data from China and Europe were encouraging, and there were reports of progress in trade negotiations with China.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our continued patient stance seemed appropriate, and the Committee saw no strong case for adjusting our policy rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the weeks since our last meeting, the crosscurrents have reemerged.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth indicators from around the world have disappointed, on net, raising concerns about the strength of the June 19, 2019 global economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Apparent progress on trade turned to greater uncertainty, and our contacts in Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL business and agriculture report heightened concerns over trade developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These concerns may have contributed to the drop in business confidence in some recent surveys and may be starting to show through to incoming data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Risk sentiment in financial markets has deteriorated as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Against this backdrop, inflation remains muted.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While the baseline outlook remains favorable, the question is whether these uncertainties will continue to weigh on the outlook and thus call for additional monetary policy accommodation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many FOMC participants now see that the case for a somewhat more accommodative policy has strengthened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me explain the basis for this judgment, starting with the outlook for jobs and growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participants see unemployment remaining low this year and next.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Monthly job gains in May were lower than expected, however, and, in light of recent developments, this bears watching.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Still, many labor market indicators remain strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Community, business, and labor leaders all tell us that the prospects for job seekers have seldom been better, and that this is true even for those who have traditionally struggled to find work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wages are rising, and this is particularly so for lower-paying jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Committee participants’ growth projections from 2019 are little revised from March, with a central tendency of 2 percent to 2.2 percent, just above their estimates of longer-run normal growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The growth projections for the year as a whole mask some important details about the composition of growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Annual growth will be boosted by the surprisingly strong first quarter, which had just been reported at the time of the May FOMC meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I noted then, the unexpected strength was largely in net exports and inventories—components that are not generally reliable indicators of ongoing momentum.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The more reliable drivers of growth in the June 19, 2019 economy are spending on consumption and business investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While consumption was weak Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL in the first quarter, incoming data show that it has bounced back and is now running at a solid pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, the limited evidence available at this time suggests that growth in business fixed income has slowed in the second quarter.1 Moreover, manufacturing production has posted declines so far this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thus, while the baseline outlook remains favorable, many FOMC participants cited the investment picture and weaker business sentiment and the crosscurrents I mentioned earlier as supporting their judgment that the risk of less favorable outcomes has risen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: After running close to our symmetric 2 percent objective for most of last year, inflation declined in the first quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Data since then show some pickup.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participants broadly see inflation moving back up toward our 2 percent objective, but at a slower pace than had been expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The central tendency for 2019 core inflation, which omits volatile food and energy components, is between 1.7 and 1.8 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Setting aside short-term fluctuations, Committee participants expressed concerns about the pace of inflation’s return to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wages are rising, as noted above, but not at a pace that would provide much upward impetus to inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Moreover, weaker global growth may continue to hold inflation down around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are firmly committed to our symmetric 2 percent inflation objective, and we are well aware that inflation weakness that persists even in a healthy economy could precipitate a difficult-to-arrest downward drift in longer-run inflation expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Because there are no definitive measures of inflation expectations, we must rely on imperfect proxies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Market-based measures of inflation compensation have moved down since our May meeting, and some survey-based expectations measures are near the bottom of their historic ranges.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Combining these 1 Chair Powell intended to say that growth in business fixed investment slowed in the second quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: June 19, 2019 factors with the risks to growth already noted, participants expressed concerns about a more Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL sustained shortfall of inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, our policy discussions focused on the appropriate response to the uncertain environment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The projections of appropriate policy show that many participants believe that some cut in the federal funds rate will be appropriate in the scenario that they see as most likely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Though some participants wrote down policy cuts and others did not, our deliberations made clear that a number of those who wrote down a flat rate path agree that the case for additional accommodation has strengthened since our May meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This added accommodation would support economic activity and inflation’s return to our objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Uncertainties surrounding the baseline outlook have clearly risen since our last meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is important, however, that monetary policy not overreact to any individual data point or short-term swing in sentiment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Doing so would risk adding even more uncertainty to the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thus, my colleagues and I will be looking to see whether these uncertainties will continue to weigh on the outlook, and we will use our tools as appropriate to sustain the expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will be pleased to take your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the Committee had, you know, our usual long discussion of global and domestic economic and financial conditions and then spent this morning talking about monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I came to the view that I expressed to you, which is that we’re going to be monitoring—monitoring the crosscurrents and the other items that we’ve mentioned, but that June 19, 2019 we’d like to see more going forward.

sentence: Particularly, we’d like to see whether these risks continue Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL to weigh on the outlook.

sentence: Only seven weeks ago, we had a great jobs report and came out of the last FOMC meeting feeling that the economy, and our policy, was in a good place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we want to see—we want to see and we want to react to developments and trends that are sustained, that are genuine, and not react just to data points or just to changes in sentiment, which can be volatile.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the same time, we are—we’re quite mindful of the risks to the outlook and are prepared to move and use our tools as needed to sustain the expansion.

sentence: Yeah, so I would say that we’re not looking at any one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I guess I would start by agreeing with your premise that news about trade has been an important driver of sentiment in the intermeeting period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re also looking at global growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s really trade developments and concerns about global growth that are on our minds.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do see, though, some areas that we’re looking at, such as, I mentioned, business fixed income.2 So—also, the prolonged shortfall in inflation and perhaps job growth—we don’t like to look at one job report.

sentence: We like to average over three or six months, but still that bears watching.

sentence: And we’ll be asking the question whether those risks are going to continue to weigh on the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then, in the end, we’ll use our tools as appropriate to sustain this long expansion.

sentence: I think the law is clear that I have a four-year term, and I fully intend to serve it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re always trying to balance that risk, but I would say that, given the quite recent nature of some of the events, I think the Committee felt, though, that the right thing to do was to wait and see more.

sentence: And we will see a lot more on all of these issues in the very near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me let me say the same thing as I said the last time, before there had been any dissents, and that is that I think the process of careful, thoughtful dissent is a very healthy one, and I’ve always believed that.

sentence: I would add, though, that the support Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL for the path we took for the policy statement that we adopted was quite broad.

sentence: You know, I would think that, to the extent you see stronger financial conditions and stronger activity in the ECB after a rate cut, that would support—tend to support activity.3 So we’re really focused on, you know, the risks to our—on the baseline outlook, which is still a pretty favorable one, and the risks to those outlooks.

sentence: You know, there are potential benefits here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are also potential risks, particularly of a currency that could, you know, that could potentially have large application.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would echo what Governor Carney said, which is that we will wind up having quite high expectations, from a sort of safety and soundness and regulatory standpoint, if they do decide to go forward with something.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we have—we don’t have plenary authority over cryptocurrencies as such.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They play into our world through consumer protection and money laundering and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, I would say that, you know, through international forums, you know, we have significant input into the payment system and, as you know, play an important role in the payment system here in the United States.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have—we’ve said that we wouldn’t look at raising the target rate for inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We did say that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the reason is, it’s become a global norm, 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our statutory mandate is price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we’re actually taking a less—we’re looking at less radical ideas, such as how to make the 2 percent inflation objective more credible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This gives me a chance to say a couple things about the review and Chicago, in particular.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a new thing for us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s something that—I thought it was both appropriate and important for us to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll be a yearlong, or even longer, process, looking at our strategy, tools, and communications.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s meant to be a way to open ourselves up, to let the sunshine in, and have dialogue and criticism with the constituencies that we serve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve had a series of Fed Listens around the country at every Reserve Bank, and we had an academic conference earlier this month, with seven papers written and criticized, and leading global experts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I’ll just say, again, that the heart of the conference was the two panels on—with practitioners in low and moderate income—who live in low- and moderate-income communities and are part of those communities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they were—there, I think, people were quite struck by their intervention, which was really uniformly around how important maximum employment is June 19, 2019 and what it means in their communities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the idea being, they haven’t had, you know, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL a bull market in these communities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They haven’t had, just, a booming economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What they have had is low unemployment, lots of social problems.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And just now, you have, you know, companies who want to hire and are bringing people into the—providing opportunities for people to come into the labor force to an extent not seen in quite a long time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that is, I think, you know, for someone who does this work, that was very focusing and motivating, too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think everybody thought, you know, that’s—that was really quite worth doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, there was some thought at the beginning that we should—some people recommended that we just talk to, you know, econ Ph.D.’s about this, but, no, that’s not what we chose to do, and we’re glad this is the choice we made.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think it’s—I don’t think it’s a practical alternative.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ll tell you why.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think you see disinflationary pressures around the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see central banks having a hard time getting inflation up to their—close to their objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve done better than other large central banks that are not, you know, open economies, like the U.K., where you have big currency moves that move inflation around.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but it’s quite challenging to get inflation—it’s been—even with very high levels of resource utilization, inflation has been lingering and not getting back up to target in a sustained, symmetric kind of a way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So saying that you’re going to go for 4 percent—I wonder how credible that will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the 2013 guidance is not binding, and that’s what came out of the GAO review.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s really the beginning of this—of the story.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we have the authority we need to examine the banks for safety and soundness exposure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, this—the first thing you start with as a bank supervisor is the risks that the banks are taking to themselves through their portfolio, through the risks that they’re running and the pipeline—you know, the obligations that they’ve undertaken to underwrite deals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we monitor that very carefully—so do the banks—and you see exposures that are much smaller than they were before the crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, we test that regularly in the stress tests.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We impose very large losses on those portfolios, so we kind of have a sense of what that is, whereas before the crisis, there was a lot of lack of knowledge about what the losses would be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s where it starts for us in supervision, is the risks that the banks are running—you know, running on their own books and to themselves and to each other.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in that, I feel—I feel like that is—that’s in a good place, but we never—we never say “Mission accomplished” on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will keep—you know, keep monitoring that carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What’s happened, though, is, the paper is now owned by market-based vehicles: collateralized loan obligations, mutual funds, and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we now have—you know, we have a good sense of, domestically, of where that paper is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think, internationally, not as much, and the Financial Stability Board is actually looking more carefully at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we—you know, we monitor those vehicles to see what they are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they’re actually pretty stably funded, in the sense that there’s no run risk, but there’s still macroeconomic risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, this is something that we take very seriously and that the FSOC, the Financial Stability Oversight Council, is looking at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we call it out as a macroeconomic risk, but it’s not really a financial stability risk, in the sense that it could undermine the ability of the financial system to do its job of intermediating credit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I think the issue isn’t that the banks don’t understand what the rules are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The issue is that the risk isn’t in the banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s in—it’s out in those market-based vehicles.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t, I don’t—you know, I no longer am day-to-day involved in this as I was before I took this job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But my sense is, though, that that’s really not the problem.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not saying it’s perfect, but I think we do understand what risks the banks are running.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re very carefully assessing that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we June 19, 2019 continue to take all these risks seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I gave a whole speech about this a few Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL weeks ago, so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we have to be closer, because more jobs are being created than people are entering the labor force.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate is lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, by just lots and lots of numbers, the labor market is in a good place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You mentioned wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the level of wages is very consistent with what it should be, in the sense that it’s approximately equal to inflation plus productivity increases on an hourly basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what’s, I guess, a little surprising, though, is that you could reach these levels of unemployment late—you know, long into a cycle, let’s say, and not see even higher wages that are pushing up on inflation, because wages at this level, even though they’re growing at a healthy rate, at an appropriate rate, they’re not growing at a rate that would provide much upward thrust for inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we watch—we watch all of this very carefully, and I think we’re very careful about not assuming that we’re, you know, that would—that there’s no more slack in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ve all lived through—you know, when I got to the Fed, we were in the 8 percent–plus range, and it’s just gone down and down and down, and you haven’t seen wages picked up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You haven’t seen real signals that we’re at maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have June 19, 2019 seen a tightening labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it—the surveys that I mentioned will all show that Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the labor market has tightened, but not overtightened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, of course, we haven’t made any decisions yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Balance sheet runoff is very close to the end of its planned life.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say this: If we do provide more accommodation—again, we haven’t really addressed this—but if we do provide more accommodation, we’ll certainly keep in mind what we said earlier this year, which is that we’ll always be willing to adjust balance sheet policy so that it serves our dual-mandate objectives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you very much.
